awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Proposal: Central States Mathematics Undergraduate Research Conferences
awd_abstract_narration:
This National Science Foundation award supports the fourth and fifth in the previously funded, successful series of Central States Mathematics Undergraduate Research (CeSMUR) conferences that will take place on April 20-21, 2018 in Lincoln, Nebraska, and in spring 2019 in Manhattan, Kansas, respectively. Research experience is very helpful in both the graduate application process, and in placement in technically demanding jobs. The scientific activities and mentoring interactions at CeSMUR are designed to encourage undergraduate students who are already engaged in research, and to inspire others to begin.
 
The conference is comprised of one and a half days. The format follows the one successfully tested in previous editions. Two main speakers each give a one-hour lecture, and there is ample time for undergraduate student speakers to present their research. During the evening and lunch meetings students interact with the featured speakers and guest graduate students in attendance, and get advice on the next steps in their career. In addition to a commitment to increasing the number of highly trained STEM professionals, the conferences focus on increasing diversity in the mathematical workforce, via participation of first generation college students, females, and underrepresented minority groups.  Further details regarding the 2018 CeSMUR conference can be found on the conference website: https://www.math.unl.edu/events/cesmur.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The CeSMUR (Central States Undergraduate Mathematics Research) series of conferences was designed to bring together undergraduate researchers in the Central States but also from across the Nation. These young researchers gave talks about their work, particpated in panels about graduate school, and networked with other undergraduate researchers, graduate students, local and guest faculty, and graduate directors from the region. Many of the student speakers came from small colleges without a doctoral, or a graduate program altogether in mathematics. The organizers made it a point to invite  keynote speakers who would showcase both traditional mathematics research,  as well as the many aspects of mathematics and quantitative sciences, especially its uses in artificial intelligence and statistics, the cross-fertilization between these three fields, and the impacts on our daily llives of the use of these novel tools. 

In addition to the spakers, many undergtaduate and graduate students as well as faculty from the hosting institution and from the region participated in the conference. Meals catered on site offered opportunity for camaraderie and cross-generational as well as cross-school interaction. The Kansas State University math club hosted after dinner math games. 

A website for the series of conerenecs is kept at Kansas State University Mathematics Department, under the the url math.ksu.edu/research/centers-groups/i-center/cesmur/ . This web location contains links to all editions of this conference series, including the names and affiliations of the keynote and student speakers, the titles and abstracts of their presentations, and schedules showing the additional professional development activities offered.
